content:
0, 2011
												A great FPS/RPG game.  It’s longer then most normal games with tons of replay ability and I’m still finding stuff I’ve never discovered.  NV also makes for a good follow up to Fallout 3, as they are build off the same engine and for the most part have very similar play style.  On top of that they reworked combat outside of VATS to make if feel more fluid with the ability to actually shoot down your sights even at low level over FO3.   Another improvement was to repairs for weapons were now you can fix a gun to max condition even with low repair  vs FO3 not letting you do that.  Lastly the change to companions and making them more useful over FO3 is great.  I liked having companions to help out and all of them have missions and stories their own that add even more to narrative of the world you play in.New Vegas does come with a little baggage (Few bugs/CTD) but other then that, as long you have auto save on your ok.  The only thing that puts me off little on this game is it don't really have the apocalypse feel as much as FO3 does.  I'm ok with the more old western feel but I do miss the large destroyed city feel most of FO3 had.  Mods also can help add to your world, change whatever you want.  You choose how things turn out but as always, war… war never changes.***9.5/10***

content:
0, 2014
												Fallout: New Vegas is all about more. There's more to do in New Vegas than in Fallout 3, its superb predecessor; there's more complexity to its gameplay mechanics; and there are even more secrets to uncover as you roam the postapocalyptic wastes. Fallout: New Vegas' familiar rhythm will delight fans of the series, and the huge world, expansive quests, and hidden pleasures will have you itching to see what other joys you might uncover. Occasional glitches and performance issues occasionally intrude upon your travels, along with the scorpions and geckos that might accost you. Don't let the quirks frighten you away, however: New Vegas' nooks and crannies are bursting with grimy treasures waiting to be dusted off and admired by intrepid explorers.There's a wild, wonderful world outside Vegas, just waiting to be explored.This latest trip into the desolate American landscape possesses many of the same elements that made Fallout 3 such a successful role-playing game, but its story doesn't boast as many memorable moments. The large-scale combat scenarios are less epic, and the surprises are less dramatic than Fallout 3's mid-game reverie. Nevertheless, the main tale provides a solid skeleton from which to hang a dumbfounding number of tasks and stand-alone parables. Many of these quests are lengthy, and great dialogue and good voice acting will invite you to learn more about the characters, as well as keep you wondering about what will happen next. A society of ghouls with pie-in-the-sky aspirations is creepy enough to make you squirm, yet blind devotion to their dreams still inspires empathy. Socialites in formal attire run a casino known for its creative menu choices, and if you play your cards right, you might get to make a menu alteration of your own. You investigate the disappearance of a sharp-tongued wife in one town and bring star-crossed lovers together in another. Some of the most fascinating occurrences are the wittier ones. During one quest, a robot with a specialized skill and a gut-busting name might offer a service that surely no game character has ever offered before. A poet in an unlikely place mumbles aloud his difficulties in finding the right rhymes. Like with Fallout 3, the greatest delights aren't in the central storyline but on its periphery.While the tale isn't as evocative as it might have been, the way it blossoms as you advance, giving you any number of ways to proceed, is extraordinary. The choices you make might lead to a dramatically different experience from another player's experience. The same is true of many supplementary quests. There's a ton of flexibility in how you might approach certain tasks. Maybe you'll fend off the robots defending a long-forgotten museum, but you might also steal an identification card that allows you to walk around (mostly) unharmed. You might provide a drug addict his fix, but if your speech skill is high enough, you can convince him to get on the straight and narrow. One lovelorn fellow will try to send you on a scavenger hunt for spare parts, but a high science skill means you can recommend another schematic and avoid the job altogether. However, there are certain cases in which the game funnels you down a specific path that might come as a shock if you prefer peaceful ends but are forced into a combat scenario with a single viable solution. And in certain cases, the quests just aren't designed particularly well. Searching for a key in a vault overrun with vegetation can turn into a major hassle. Avoiding an artillery bombardment isn't fun in the least and feels out of place given the measured pace at which you move. And an optional quest in which you hop from one computer terminal to another to isolate a virus leads to frustrating trial-and-error guesswork.Ghouls don't like it when you say 'eewww' to their faces. It's better to talk behind their backs at a later time.Large personalities give an edge to your undertakings. A mysterious man known as Mr. House presides over both the Strip, as well as your own adventures, and his singular focus on fulfilling his needs looms dramatically over the later hours of your escapades. The leader of a Roman-inspired legion is also an ominous presence and a violent counterpoint to the upright and learned leader of the Brotherhood of Steel's local contingent. A ghoulish ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, a potty-mouthed head waiter, and a wealthy-but-desperate father all make an impression in spite of their very minor roles. You might even find an interesting kindred spirit to accompany you. As with Fallout 3, you can bring a companion along with you; this is handy not only in combat, but it also gives you an extra inventory for dumping detritus. Interacting with your companion is simple, thanks to a wheel that lets you choose behaviors for your fellow traveler. You can only have one at a time, but you'll encounter multiple individuals willing to join you, and they all make interesting and funny quips when you interact with them. They also open up different quest opportunities, giving you a chance to learn more about what makes them tick.Fallout: New Vegas' major addition is that of faction favor. You establish a reputation with various towns and organizations by doing them favors or annoying them in some way or another. Which factions you align with has both subtle and profound consequences. If you're liked, a random somebody might run up to you bearing minor gifts, such as an iguana on a stick. (Mmm, tasty.) Or if you've gained a more violent reputation, a mugger might accost you with violent intentions, only to run off when he recognizes you. It's a pleasure to hear random citizens remark on how they feel about you as you pass by, even if the canned comments repeat a bit too often. (It's sometimes bizarre to hear two characters standing side by side deliver the same line, spoken by the same voice actor.)That Great Khan is no match for a sword made out of a bumper.Your faction relationships also have much more dramatic consequences on your adventure, opening up new quests while closing off others. The game is sometimes a bit opaque regarding how your actions may inadvertently affect the way a particular faction sees you, but this complexity manifests itself in awesome ways as you near the end of your travels. One great twist to this system is that by dressing up in faction-specific clothing or armor, you can disguise yourself and avoid a confrontation. Though, conversely, you might get dragged into battles against allies if you forget to change gear, which might damage a relationship you're trying to cultivate. This reputation system is a bit abstract, but it's a great addition to the Fallout formula, adding even more layers to a template already lauded for its flexibility.Glitches may give you a few minor fits, but the PC version of Fallout: New Vegas is not in the same rough technical shape as its console counterparts, possibly thanks to a sizeable patch delivered a day after its release. That doesn't mean there aren't problems here. We encountered some bugs, such as a friendly quest giver inexplicably attacking us, even though he didn't show as an enemy on the directional radar. Characters might still randomly freak out as if you're about to attack for no discernible reason, only to return to their normal locations a moment later and act as if nothing had happened. But we encountered only a few scripting problems, and the game never crashed. Most complex role-playing games suffer from technical hitches, and this one is no exception. However, the oddities in this version aren't exceptionally disruptive, which makes it easy to stay invested.Hacking is one way to solve your problems, but if you aren't good at it, there's probably another way. Or three.If you played Fallout 3 or The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion, which used the same game engine as Fallout: New Vegas, then you won't be surprised by some of the other minor foibles, although many of them seem exac

content:
ber 16, 2013
												Fallout New Vegas really reminds the player of the original fallouts.Unlike Fallout 3 (which i highly recommend as well) New Vegas gives you choices that you may be morally conflicted with, yes Fallout 3 had choices in it, all good fallout games have, but New Vegas gives you more options. In addition to more choices the developers have introduced a reputation system, you do something good like help a community you will be liked more, but if you do things they do not like your reputation will go down. All of this matters in the endgame, who will support you depending on what side you took.Like many of RPG you will encounter people, you will talk to people. Throughout your travels you will meet interesting people you either like or dislike, all characters of importance are interesting, they have a story to tell, from Mr House overlord of the strip to the super mutants in Jacobstown.The graphics honestly are not anything to brag about. There is little change from Fallout 3, a few things have been brought over. But Fallout has never been known for their graphics, it has been for the story. If you are really bugged by the graphics you could just go and get a mod for it, there are plenty.VATS is back, along with other gameplay elements that made Fallout 3 popular. There have been changes made as well, more immersive elements have been added, like making ammunition, more crafting options, more weapons types, gambling and many more. I would not be recommending this game if there was no change, but there is change and it is a good change.Active community, Mods! The community is super active for mods, so many mods mods mods mods.Lastly the DLC. Lonesome road, Dead money, Old Wolrd Blues and honest hearts. All of them are good in their own respects but this review is looking at the core game, reviews for the DLC's will be on their respective pages or elsewhere.Fallout New Vegas is a game that is a game I will definitely recommend to anybody that asks.

 I just love this gameI played it without Steam some years ago for about 150+ hours and want to recapitulate this experience now with some Nexus-mods. Took me about 4 hours to get it running smoothly and without crashes, but it's totally worth the time and money!! For me  NMC-textures and Nevada Skies crashed the whole game. So this was a bummer. I recommend the following mods:  Western Sky!!  Active Wasteland  db enhanced Blood Textures  Full Character Overhaul!  Improved Sound FX!!  Sprint Mod  NVAC - New Vegas Anti Crash  EVE - Essential Visual Enhancements!!  The radio stations: CONELRAD and Old World RadioI also recommend to start the game in Windows 7 compatibility mode (Windows XP Service Pack 2).But also without mods and stuff this game is absolutely great and except the grafics totally up to date! If you're from Germany, be shure to buy the UNCUT Ultimate Edition!!For More Blood etc. open Fallout_default.ini Config file found in:...Steam\steamapps\common\fallout new vegasand find the following lines:fDecalLifetime=10.0000iMaxDecalsPerFrame=50change the numbers to:fDecalLifetime=720.0000iMaxDecalsPerFrame=512 Bottom line: This is one of the best RPG of all time and can keep up with games like Morrowind and Skyrim!Update: It's still running pretty good, but every 2-3 hours it's crashing...But so what?!Update after 150 hours: Done most of the side-quests and it's still fun to scavenge and explore the wastelands. There's sooooo much to discover and I realized that last time I played it I missed many many cool quests and locations.Right now, I'm starting the Dead Money DLC with my level 34 character. This DLC seems to be quite out of touch with the "normal" Fallout NV world. There's something about ghosts, radios which will kill you if you go near them (you're wearing a booby-trap-collar (Battle Royale?!), which will detonate on approach) and some guy is forcing you to enter the Sierra Madre casino with some companions...Mhh, I'm eager to find out how this turns out!! I'll keep you updated!Update: Okay, totally got addicted again to this game! Played every DLC and maxed my character out...Mhhh, let's see, how long it takes until I play it again :-DI WILL BE BACK!!Update:   Okay, maybe I won't be back, because, people, hear me out: FALLOUT 4 HAS BEEN ANNOUNCED!!!  So for all of you who can't wait, get this game and prepare yourself for the wasteland!!

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
1, 2014
												War? War never changes. Neither does Fallout. Between Fallout 3 and New Vegas not a whole lot had changed. Heck, usually a sequel adds significant technical improvements. Not New Vegas. New Vegas trades out the setting for a slightly different one, trades in its story for something that Bioware would be jealous of. And adds a few new weapons and options. Other than that, New Vegas and Fallout 3 are pretty much exactly alike. And that is not a bad thing. I would have loved a more intuitive interface, or higher walkspeed, but I guess the developers held true to their creed of "do not fix what isn't broke." They also didn't fix was was broken, but big games have these small issues, and New Vegas is big. Huge. Ginormous. Not just in scale, but also in scope. There are so incredibly many things to do; if you'd try to do them all, you'd go mad. It is impossible to do it all in one playthrough; many quests have different angles and outcomes, and your alignment plays a big role. Oh, and this game isn't cushy with good and bad alignment. No, this game has a tonne of factions, and each keeps tabs on your relationship with them. You can suck up to all of them, or a few, or just go full paraiah and just kill everyone. Also, the game generally doesn't care about how you finish up a quest; just that you put an end to it. New Vegas is a true, and both technically and literally a sandbox game. Most of the world is desert. Miles and miles of barren, irradiated sand, rocks and broken roads. This is where the tedium sets in. Because for all its superfluence, there isn't much variation in the design. All the buildings look the same. Someone built the same dingy shack about 18 times over, all across the Mohave desert. You can only distiguish the various derelict factories from the name on the door. It's a shame. For all its complex relationship mechanics and over the top gore, it is easy to see where the developers cut costs.None of it really matters. The narrative just sucks you in, then spits you out to the side so you can go fishing for airplanes, only to draw you back in as you are rummaging through random hotel rooms. When you finally hit the climax, you'll have no idea about what and who you were working with. All the more reason to play it again, and waste even more time, looking for snowglobes in a giant desert while the future of mankind is at the mercy of antiquated fanatics who like to nail people to crosses for fun. Serious business.

content:
0, 2011
												A great FPS/RPG game.  It’s longer then most normal games with tons of replay ability and I’m still finding stuff I’ve never discovered.  NV also makes for a good follow up to Fallout 3, as they are build off the same engine and for the most part have very similar play style.  On top of that they reworked combat outside of VATS to make if feel more fluid with the ability to actually shoot down your sights even at low level over FO3.   Another improvement was to repairs for weapons were now you can fix a gun to max condition even with low repair  vs FO3 not letting you do that.  Lastly the change to companions and making them more useful over FO3 is great.  I liked having companions to help out and all of them have missions and stories their own that add even more to narrative of the world you play in.New Vegas does come with a little baggage (Few bugs/CTD) but other then that, as long you have auto save on your ok.  The only thing that puts me off little on this game is it don't really have the apocalypse feel as much as FO3 does.  I'm ok with the more old western feel but I do miss the large destroyed city feel most of FO3 had.  Mods also can help add to your world, change whatever you want.  You choose how things turn out but as always, war… war never changes.***9.5/10***

content:
4, 2016
												Fallout: New Vegas is easily and undeniably one of the single greatest games of all time (at least in my opinion). From the moment Ron Perlman mutters the simple opening line to the point in which you look back upon all that you have accomplished before your final decision at Hoover Dam, you experience a world filled with colorful landmarks and memorable people. On the surface, the game and its world seem crude, dirty, and vulgar but once that surface is cracked and you look inwards, you see an arrangement of mysteries and philosophies all waiting to be explored and experienced. Unfortunately, nothing can be perfect, every shining jewel is tarnished in some way or another- and in the case of New Vegas? The game is broken and unstable. You can not spend an hour in the game without experiencing the consequenses of an incredibly low budget and a development time of less than 2 years. Clipping issues, assets becoming distorted, quests not allowing you to progress, and so on. Not to mention the crashing. The game has some of the most insufferable crashes, often forcing you to sign out or restart your PC entirely. The final drawback of the game is its graphics. The game is ugly. It recieved no enhancement over Fallout 3. In fact, a noticeable percentage of assets and textures are borrowed directly from its predecessor. Of course all of these problems listed can be fixed with one simple method: mods. As one of the most heavily modded games of all time, its very difficult to run out of content, whether it be vanilla or added in at your discretion. Six years later and I still play this game regularly, and I'm hoping that Obsidian is given one more chance at the helm of the Fallout franchise.(Oct 2016) Nvidia and Windows have made this game absolutely unplayable. Can't even load a save, the game just automatically crashes. Thanks for the memories, New Vegas. We will never forget you

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
9, 2014
												Before you read this review - let me just say this: buy it. Just buy it.Fallout New Vegas is a FPS/3rd-person/RPG/adventure game hybrid that for most gamers it would be common to compare with Skyrim. Because after all, the two games were developed by the same company. Almost. Bethesda and Obsidian respectively  Based upon an equal foundation, at least. But New Vegas is so much more than Skyrim in a post-apocalypse setting.New Vegas shows some of the most intriguing, creative, funny and emotional writing that I've ever experienced in a game. It sets the perfect tone with the western post apocalyptic 1960's combined with a bunch of Vegas Baby-backdrop for an adventure about war, ruthless criminals, survival, and endless discoveries. It encourages an alternative approach with a seriously dialogue-driven storyline. With you as a participant, you can influence almost everything that happens. IF you're a charismatic speaker. If not...well, I guess you could go for the (ATTACK) option. This bothers me much with other games, because there's usually no "pacifist" game mechanic, you usually end up straining yourself to avoid things the game want you to do, because it doesnt tailor to what you want for yourself. This is not the case with New Vegas. If you want this or that to be the fallout (meh) of your several quest and individual storylines, it's fine. It's possible. The combat may feel a bit disjointed and "hack'n'slash"-like, with little weight behind motions. I would like more impact. There's not really much physics involved, except for the ragdolls when someone dies, lol. Even that is lackluster.Graphics... pretty..bland. At least my vanilla game (the normal, not modded version) doesn't really drag me into an immersive world, and it hasn't aged that well. BY ITSELF. Not anymore. that's my curse though, I'm a bit stuck up when it comes to graphics and visuals. I just didn't manage to get AS into it as I used to. Then I started modding, and got ENBs functional. My Fallout now looks incredible, runs good, and for me is one of the most complete experiences to date.When I get past my own cursed liking for good visuals, and actually got the game looking sweet... There's nothing bothering me with this game. The writing and story, the characters, locations, the exploration, the factions you fight for and against, the dynamic and deep companions, the action and reaction, consequences of your choices, and how it's all just...Its a good trip.One of my favorite games. No doubt. about 40 hours checked on this playthrough, and I haven't even reached the Strip!A couple of years ago I got 100+ hours without a hitch.Ring-a-ding-ding baby

content:
r 9, 2015
 Fallout: New Vegas Alright, before you read the rest of my review let me get one thing straight, on the whole "Fallout 3 vs. Fallout: New Vegas" argument,  I believe Fallout: New Vegas is better  in my opinion Fallout: New Vegas is better than Fallout 3, now hold on, before you call me the devil himself,  I don't dislike Fallout 3 by any means  , it's still one of my favorite games of all time, I just believe that New Vegas is better. I'll be going over my reasoning for believing that New Vegas is better and generally comparing it to FO3 a lot.First of all we'll have to go over some pros for Fallout: New Vegas Fallout: New Vegas Pros  Improved Gameplay Mechanics: One of the biggest improvements over FO3 is the improved mechanics such as the widely improved crafting system, the weapon modification system, ironsights, nerfed VATS, gambling, and etc. Improved Character System Mechanics: Faction system, better karma system, almost no essential (unkillable) characters, hardcore mode Branching Storylines: One awesome addition was the branching storylines (I'll cover the FO3 storyline later) one great thing about the branching storylines was the replayability, I'm about the do my 4th playthrough of the game, the factions you could choose from are the  New California Republic, Caesar's Legion, Mr. House, and Independant Vegas.  Modding: The game itself is amazing, and mods just make it more enjoyable, fix bugs, or add more content, it's all there within the Fallout: New Vegas modding community. Fallout: New Vegas Cons  Bugs: FO:NV, just like any other Fallout game, or Bethesda games for that matter, are plagued with bugs. Whether it's clipping into the ground, mission glitches that make them uncompletable, or missing textures, even though a mod has probably been made or a guide that can be found with a quick Google search. Similarities: One problem I had when first playing is how it was too much was similar with Fallout 3 such as the user interface and it just felt like a Fallout 3 reskin at first. Fallout: New Vegas and Fallout 3 Comparisons  World Design: I personally like the vibe that FO3 gives off more than FO:NV, while New Vegas gives off a "humanity rebuilding" feel, FO3 focuses on the apocalypse more and I personally like that about FO3, when I was gambling in casinos on the New Vegas strip it sometimes felt like a Las Vegas Simulator. Storyline: So this was my main gripe with Fallout 3, it's storyline, you would think I would have some choice, in Fallout: New Vegas there were 4 different storylines, all with different missions, and even side missions would affect the endings Fallout: New Vegas Verdict 
 9/10

												One of the Best Apolalyptic RPG games out thereStory 9/10Gamplay 9/10Replayable 10/10Achievement 7/10Fallout New Vegas is the fourth installment to the Fallout franchise. This game is a big step up from the previous game Fallout 3, one of my all time favourite games. It added more of a survival aspect and weapon upgrading to the already ideal nuclear apolalyptic world of Fallout. It seems that Bethesda wanted to take this game into more of a cowboy feel to it and  move away from the big city and the Brotherhood of Steel heavy power armour to the deserted Mojave wasteland with the NCR soldier look and The Legion Roman battle armour. Adding new and old weapons to aid on your journeybut still keeping the same look and style of Fallout 3. This game uses idea and references from the previous game studio Blackisle Studios plan for their Fallout 3 before Bethesda rebooted the franchise with more of a first person shooter.The story can be told in many ways and the actions that you take on your journey as the courier, the choices that you make truly make your character to survive the wasteland.At this time the game is easy and cheap to buy the game and all the DLCs and not break the bank but adding more whispers in the wind of the Mojave wasteland from the  science labs of Big Mountain to the cloud ridden get away Sierra Madre to the forgotten Divine, or to travel to an untouched land where the trees are green.I recommend this game to anyone that enjoys the idea of apocalyptic worlds where you are the creator of your free will.Cause.War, War Never Changes.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
1, 2014
												Fallout: New Vegas is pretty much the post-apocalypse game I always wanted. You have a gigantic world to explore, countless number of side quests in addition to the already meaty and choice-based main quest The gameplay is satisfying and is is the perfect balance between RPG and action shooter. The game easily has over 150 hours of content with all the DLC. It is a proper RPG, letting you play how you want, be it a suave diplomat, a sneaky thief, or a thug with a very big hammer, and has multiple factions to side with for the end-game.As someone who played the hell out of this on the Xbox, I got the game again on PC primarily for mods, and if anyone is considering re-buying for that reason, I whole heartedly say do it right now. Modding makes an already great game fantastic and utterly unique to you with thousands upon thousands of mods. Never a fan of any of the armour or weapons? There is probably a mod out there for you. Not a fan of the fast travel system? Get XRE cars and drive around the wasteland. Have Fallout 3 and want one huge game? Get Tale of Two Wastelands and combine them into one big game with the same character. Want the game to be less of an RPG and more of a shooter, with high damage numbers, sprinting and hotkeys for grenades and melee? There are indeed mods that do that. The possibilities are endless, and the main modding website for New Vegas is easy to use, letting you both manually install mods or have an app that does it for you if you aren't confident enough or unsure.  Pretty much any kind of mod you want, it's out there.The main downside to a game of this scope if the stability, and while generally stable there are some very common bugs everyone will come across when playing the game. Of course, if you have played any other Bethesda-style RPG you will expect this anyway. I made a post on the forums which has the main ones you will need to make the game stable and mostly bug free:http://steamcommunity.com/app/22380/discussions/0/522730700736948013/I can not recommend this game highly enough. One of the best RPG's of the last generation. If you want to see how awesome this game looks, check out my screenshots.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
5, 2014
												Easily one of the best RPGs out there. The engine is a bit outdated, but still makes a great Job in being fun. Specially if you mod the ♥♥♥♥ outta it. Skyrim may have better graphics, and be more stable, but like most Elder Scrolls games, it lacks roleplaying. The TES saga is great for it's lore and dungeoncrawling. But in New Vegas you can REALLY play a different character. You can be a gay guy who's a smooth talker and doesn't need to fire a shot to get ♥♥♥♥ done, for example. The different ways to solve the quests, according to your skills is what makes the Fallout saga really great. Of course, that's not the only thing this game has to offer. An awesome ambientation, the whole Fallout lore is so rich and unique. Since the smiling guy from the pipboy and all the 30s related humor, to a faction that tries to live by the rules of the Roman Empire, or the super mutants, and a lot more stuff. If Fallout has something that makes it different from other post apocaliyptic settings it's its humor and its uniqueness.Comparing it to Fallout 3, it's better in pretty much every way. The decisions now aren't all "be a good good person or be a evil evil man". There are more quests, more factions, a better reputation system. The companions actually have quests and personalities, you can really get to love 'em.  The combat system is better, with the weapons having iron sights and mods, and different types of ammo. Armor is more important now, etc. And to top it off, there's a really nice hardcore mode that allows you to have needs. Yes, now you need to eat, sleep and drink to survive, and can only heal limbs with the not-so-common doctor bags or by actually visiting a doctor. It definetly makes the game harder (Though it IS pretty forgiving in some aspects).The game has its flaws, obviously. The most serious being its bugs. But even like that, the game is a lot more stable than Fallout 3 and is fully playable. Anyways, I could keep talking, and I know I left various aspects of the game uncovered in this "review", but this is Just a general recomendation. If you like old RPGs where roleplaying was more important, or simply an unique and open world to explore and get into, this game is for you. Just buy it, you won't regret it.

30, 2012
												If you haven't been diagnosed with ADD prior to playing Fallout New Vegas, you definitely will be after playing it. There are so many places to explore, people to talk to, and things to do that it's difficult not to get distracted. But the game remains fun even when you happen to run off on some wild goose chase because the story flows so seamlessly. It never feels like you are on some irrelevant side mission. I love the stress-free freedom to do what you want, when you want to do it.The game left me in awe as to how intricate virtual worlds like this can be experienced in such stunning detail--definitely worth spending my time and energy. Its biggest disappointment is the inability to continue character development and exploration once the main quest is finished. You are forced to load an old save...

Pros: - Good Story - Many Quests, a lot more than Fallout 3 - Great Weapon Variety -  Good and bad voice acting - Many Followers - References to the previous fallout games - The best dlc's i have ever played - Many different paths and factions to follow - Great locations and level design  Cons: - Bugs, frequent crashing, glitches - Terrible Gunplay, you will probably rely on vats for many battles - Bad Graphics, terrible for 2010 - Character Creation is lackluster, your character will most likely not look like you  I know i probably missed many things about this game, but this is what i came up with. I recommend this game to anybody who enjoys the fallout series and the dev and published Bethesda, then this is a must have game. If you enjoy western rpg's there is no better developer and publisher, however this is developed by Obsidion, and is made in a different sort of mood than Fallout 3. This game is bright and interesting. Fallout 3 can be interesting, but it is most often dark and gloomy. This is great game that anyone who enjoys rpg's should buy.

												This review is titled: In My OpinionFallout 4:Pros: The most exploration of them all, best combat, a large city enviornment without borders, the best leveling system, base building, Far Harbor, best crafting systems and customization, most interesting companions (and are not completely broken mechanically), most badass power armor, most brutal survival mode, best setting. Not green or orange.Cons: THE ABSOLUTE WORST DLC (literally a rip-off except Far Harbor), almost zero amount of roleplaying (I dont care about that anyway tbh), you get the achievements and never play again, a slightly more classic aesthetic feel to F1-F3 but still odd like New Vegas.Fallout New Vegas:Pros: Roleplaying, decision based main questline with multiple branching paths, lots of replayability, best vault locations, best minigame (caravan), saving up caps actually matters, slaughtering factions you don't care about whenever you want, anti-material rifle (the most badass gun in any fallout game), most interesting easter eggs (and there are a lot of them).Cons: Cazadors, frustrating combat, small map size with a lot of forgettable locations, okayish DLC (some are better than others), cazadors, odd artistic style compared to F1-F3, huge amount of game breaking bugs at launch (i lost a 30 hour playthrough because of it), worst setting, cazadors, boring NPCs, Orange.Fallout 3Pros: Most memorable side quests, best plot of the main story (imo), most badass brotherhood of steel, most classic artstyle, best radio music, best radio host, best score, most interesting NPCs, best overall DLC, feels like a post-apocalyptic world, lots of locations that have depth and multiple zones.EDIT: I forgot to add Liam Neeson to the pros section because I mean... do I need to explain?Cons: Downtown is chopped into chunks that require hours of subway exploration to access different areas, large map however everything is very spread apart, more replayability then Fallout 4, but still not as much as Fallout New Vegas, NO STEAM ACHIEVEMENTS, runs like crap on Win 7+, I believe you cant aim down sights not 100% though on that, Green.

content:
er 10, 2013
Fallout: New Vegas is a Post-Apocalyptic RPG that is a great change from common Fantasy-Themed RPGsIn the game you play as a courier about 200 years in the future where america has been turned into a Post-Apocalyptic radioactive wasteland by a war with China in 2077. Small towns dot the lands, while remnants of large cities are ridden with bloodthirsty junkies and criminals. While there is so much danger in the world, there is one gem that sticks out and attracts wealthier people from all around: New Vegas. A city protected by a mysterious overseer called "Mr. House", New vegas contains gambling just as much as dirty criminals and squatters.You were delivering a package for the Mojave express when you were shot in the head and buried alive by scheming businessman and had your package stolen. You wake up in Goodsprings, a quaint town on the very outskirts of New vegas. The doctor patches you up and sends you on your way. Your Mission: find the man who tried to kill you and get revenge. On your way, you may be having to decide the fate of New Vegas, and maybe, the world.The Pros:The gameplay stays true to regular RPGs, with a balanced level system but a low cap at level 30. The game is easy to get used to and does have a more challenging mode for when you become a veteran at the game. Hardcore Mode is a mode that increases the difficulty of the game by giving ammo weight and adding hunger, thirst and the possibility of sleep deprivation. I dont reccomend playing on this mode on your first playthrough, but is a fun twist on the traditional game. The arsenal of guns is truly AMAZING, some obtainable through with expensive purchases while others you may have to do some hunting for. there are a large variety of locations in the game and there is even more if you buy the DLCs. All of them are great in my opinion but you may want to pick up lonesome road and old world blues before any of the others. Both give you interesting new areas to explore and cool storylines (lonesome road is a direct continuation of the story!) and maybe up to 10 hours each of additional gameplay. The game also has an INSANE amount of mods and a great mod community. Head over to the Fallout New Vegas Nexus for most mods.The Cons:The Graphics are a little dated since it uses the same engine as Fallout 3. The Game also does have a long tutorial period for learning the game, Which can almost stop you from replaying the game a third or fourth time. The "Dead Money" DLC is absolutely horrible, full of ugly puzzles which make you feel like you're not even playing Fallout, More like a horrible and buggy indie stealth-puzzler. The vanilla game is also buggy, some that can even stop you from progressing in the game.Despite these cons, Fallout NV is a great Shooter-RPG to pick up, and a cheap one at that! I give it an 8/10.

content:
25, 2013
												I ♥ the post-apocalyptic vegas style, with the grimy feel of what once were grand buildings, casinos and neon lit streets overlooking a vast, scarce and dangerous wasteland, full of weird and sometimes wonderful things.Customise and create how *you* want to play by altering perks, skills and attributes from the beginning and developing whilst levelling up. Shun or gain respect with different factions and choose a path of destiny with the bigger factions that play core roles in the main storyline. The game is not really too difficult in normal mode but I enjoy playing this game in hardcore mode because it adds more realism to the gameplay, where carrying ammo is counted as weight, injuries take time to heal and ensuring to keep tabs on eating, drinking and sleeping enough.The battle system uses VATS, a targetting system that is entertaining to use if  zoned in on an enemy and they happen to have the weirdest expression or pose at the time!What really creates Fallout is the psychological dialogue of the characters encountered, giving clues to a history or a side-story in the background. Some of the characters are so quirky and memorable that it made me gain a thirst for knowledge about the fallout world. I think you will ♥ this game if you enjoy a combination of RPG, FPS, exploration. Plus there is a lot of DLC to dig into along with completing the main story and exploring all of the wasteland.Overall, this is one of my most loved games and I have to recommend it as one of the best games I have played, not just for the gameplay but simply for the character and role customisation that has been presented as an adventure. ♥

content:
er 3, 2015
												"The New California Republic needs YOU strong!  Do not eat irradiated food!"Having played through Fallout 3 twice over the course of the past half of a decade, I was looking forward to giving Fallout: New Vegas a go but I always seemed to forget that it was in my library when I was choosing what my next 'main game' was going to be.  Finally, with the announcement of Fallout 4 being released in the near future, I pulled it together and started it up with the goal of completing it before the new release.  I was not disappointed.Fallout: New Vegas feels like a standalone expansion to Fallout 3.  However, this particular standalone expansion brings so much to the game that it may as well have had a 4 slapped onto the end of the title.  The roleplaying aspect is drastically improved with a faction alignment system, a balancing of the skills (all of them are extremely useful throughout the game now), and an incredible and deep storyline that alters the world and the ending based on choices that you have made throughout the game.  As opposed to saying that I enjoyed the story as I did in Fallout 3, New Vegas pulled me in and didn't let go until I'd finished the game in its entirety.The more action-FPS aspect of the game was significantly improved in this iteration as well.  Fighting outside of VATS seemed much smoother this time around and was genuinely enjoyable as opposed to merely acceptable.  Crafting was completely overhauled with several different skill lines unlocking hundreds of recipes that were invaluable at differing stages of the game.  The lands around New Vegas were a blast to explore and seemed packed full of life from one side of the map to the other.  Every trip I took across the wasteland resulted in discovering a new location to explore, a caravan being ambushed by the dreaded Caesar's Legion, or any number of other events that were a breath of life in the world.A great game, and one of my favorites now, that I highly recommend to RPG, FPS, and Post-Apocalyptic fans. I'll definitely be taking at least one more trip back into New Vegas to see what other events, quests, storylines, and endings I can discover by signing on with one of the other factions in the game.

												Orth, 3000 years in the future. The planet is a radioactive wasteland inhabited by ska-criminals, sentient rat mutants, and Fearum's deadly Waster clan. The Daybringer is the proxy agent for extrasolarian reverse-aging gas-cloud lifeforms which intend on re-arranging the events of all timelines so that only one timeline remains, freeing up valuable multiverse real estate. Jack and Jill are the most advanced paired AIs ever conceived, on a mission to sift through memories and sort out where and when The Techno Device is. Dzang-Sarang is an extradimensional refugee hoping that the other half of his body shows up at some point. The ruthless Praetarch Unless has made a deal with The Daybringer to spare this timeline, but at what cost? Dr. Tuce Dopeshow is the only man who has a handle on what's going on but he's been dead for centuries. You are Abe Stahl, a salt-and-pepper haired grifter who just wants a root beer. Chinese language only, all characters voiced by Frank Yang. 8/10

content:
5, 2016
												Fallout: New Vegas is a open word post apocalyptic role playing game developed by Obsidian Entertainment and published by Bethesda Softworks. The gameplay itself is very simlar to Fallout 3. New Vegas took Fallout 3, and gave it a new location, and vastly improved game mechanics and player choice. I think there is nothing wrong with that. Some people do not like New Vegas because of this. While it is true that New Vegas is quite reminiscent to Fallout 3 , it is not a reason to jump to conclusions and assume that the game is not good because of this. Fallout: New Vegas is an amazing game. It has tons of freedom and choice, and it lets you do whatever you want to do. The game even set up the Intro to the game in a way that you can decide who you are. You are a player with no past and have no memeory of anything. This leaves massive space for role playing. I can be a badass sheriff in one play through. In another playthrough, I could be a cold blooded asassin looking for revenge, that will do anything he needs to get what he wants. In creating a backstory for your character, your imagination is the limit. The quests in this game also do not fall short of great. There are many choices within the game, when it comes from choosing how to deal with a faction, choosing which faction to side with, choosing to kill everyone you see etc. Some choices will even test your morals and you will never really know if you made the "good choice" Speaking of good, there's another thing to mention. None of the factions in New Vegas are just good. There is no plain good faction, or plain evil faction, as they are all debatable. The political side of New Vegas is sort of morally grey. Each faction has their good side, and they also have a bad side to them. It is up to the player to make the final descision which faction they will side with. The game even shows you a slideshow before the credits showing you all of choices you made, and the outcome or consequences of those choices. It really does make you feel mixed emotions depending on how you played the game. The game also has great and memorable music, that will get stuck in your head right away! Since there are 4 factions to side with in the main quest, and tons of role play oppertunities, this game has tons of replay value. This game is a must have for any PC owner. Excuse my hours on the game, I played a lot more hours on the consoles before I had a PC. If you do get it, I recommend you get the Ultimate Edition with all the DLC, because the DLC is great, and if you are going to mod the game, a lot of mods require you to have all DLC. Good luck and have fun!I give this game 10/10 spurs!

content:
ry 17, 2015
												I have looked at this game in my review list for months, of all the titles in my back catalogue Fallout: New Vegas is by far the most daunting. I feel that regardless of to what extent I praise FNV, I will still not be doing it justice.Fallout as a series has grown from some seriously humble roots, and what it has become is one of the finest post-apocalyptic open world RPGs to date. The world is alive, desperate, detailed, immersive and a true wonder to explore. Within this incredible world are some of the most spectacularly realized NPCs and stories ever conceived by Bethesda. The last time I remember being so aware of the lives around me was when I first played Morrowind.As if the vanilla game wasn’t amazing enough, the modding community is seemingly limitless. From tower defense, to a first person shooter overhaul, to countless add on stories and scenarios, there are hundreds if not thousands of hours of content to lose yourself in. The ultimate kicker here is that Fallout: New Vegas is CONSTANTLY on sale. And not just dinky 15% off specials, during any given steam sale, FNV is almost always on sale for 2 or 3 bucks at some point. At this price, it is absolutely ridiculous not to pick up this masterpiece RPG.

content:
y 3, 2016
												Ah, fallout new vegas. A story of grit, deceit, and revenge. The story of a courier who got caught at the bad place at the worst time. After being shot and left for dead, the courier is seemingly brought back from the dead by Doc mitchell. After being let loose into the small town of goodsprings, and learning the ropes of the new survival system, you are set loose into the Nevada wastes. Dead set on revenge, the story is wonderful with many endings. Each one of your actions with the factions, your followers, the main story, the route you take, and even the smallest things (such as replacing a cyborg dogs brain ). The gameplay has not changed too much from fallout 3, using the same engine and all. The endings are all written to perfection, the legion, the ncr, and the independant vegas endings are all satisfying to accomplish. The followers system has been improved on in many ways, the most standout being the new companion wheel. Being able to give your companion stimpaks and orders is much more simple. That and the followers are amazing, and the way you recruit them is more interesting than Fallout 3. The soundtrack is what you would expect from a fallout game, 40s to 50s era music, and its wonderful. How do I know all of this with only 13 hours? I played the ♥♥♥♥ out of the playstation 3 version. The game is a must buy. Also Cazadores are my nightmare fuel.

content:
er 2, 2013
												War. War never changes. Except for the occasional crash and bugs, but that's typical of a game with little development cycle.Fallout: New Vegas is a first-person action RPG, much like its predecessor, Fallout 3. Developed by Obsidian Entertainment, it is set in the Mojave Wasteland, closer to where the original games were set. Your customizable character’s a Courier, shot and left for dead by a man named Benny interested in a package you were delivering. Following through your trail for revenge, you find that the major factions in the region--The New California Republic, Caesar’s Legion, and Mr. House--vying for complete control of the Mojave wasteland. It’s up to you whether or not any of the three, or yourself, would take over the Dam.The NCR is a lot like the US, both the good and the bad. Most of the time, they mean well. In the game, they spread out a lot, using up quite a bit of their resources to cover their new land in the process. This puts them at a disadvantage after the first battle at the Dam against the Legion. Caesar's Legion, in theory, is supposed to be the Roman Empire. But it's filled with misogyny, homophobia, and slavery. There's Mr. House, an expy of Howard Hughes. While he wants to improve humanity in his own way, he's extremely ruthless in his dealings. And there's the Wild Card path, where you set the Mojave down a path of independence and anarchy, alienating the other main factions in the process.In addition, there are four major DLCs (Dead Money, Honest Hearts, Old World Blues¸ and Lonesome Road), each having its own story, and two additional DLCs (Courier’s Stash--pre-order bonuses--and Gun Runners’ Arsenal—more weapons).I really enjoyed the game largely due to the writing, along with a lot of replayability. However, I feel that there was a lack of real motivation deciding which faction to assist in taking over Hoover Dam, and I felt that your character lacked a bit of personaity compared to other RPG characters. Even the Lone Wanderer had plenty of personality (c'mon. "No. ♥♥♥♥ you."). As mentioned earlier, there were a lot of game-breaking bugs, especially at launch. But thankfully mods and patches had gotten rid of them, but a few of them are still there, so mind where you travel.Because of the small development cycle, there are plenty of missed opportunities, like exploring Legion territories and continuing the game after the second battle of Hoover Dam. My suggestion for this game? I would recommend getting this game and its DLCs, which is easy to do with buying the Ultimite Edition. But do take your time on the Nexus; they got plenty of mods that'll enhance the game immensely.
